botanical_details.genus: Tilia are deciduous trees with broadly ovate or heart-shaped leaves and pendulous clusters of fragrant yellow-green flowers, followed by conspicuous winged fruits

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade; prefers alkaline to neutral soil but tolerant of acid conditions. Avoid very dry conditions and exposure to strong winds. Tilia trees are sometimes associated with large numbers of dead bumblebees. Scientific studies have demonstrated that this is not due to toxic nectar or pollen, but may be due to a complex interaction of weather and suboptimal nectar. It does not usually happen every year and tends to coincide with the natural end of bumblebee nests, so is unlikely to cause any larger scale problems
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by seed, layering, grafting or chip-budding onto a suitable rootstock
how_to_grow.pruning: Pruning group 1; sucker removal in winter
how_to_grow.pests: Aphids, horse chestnut scale, caterpillars, sawflies and gall mites may be a problem
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by phytophthora root diseases and honey fungus
